parts.text:
Figure 1 shows a measuring cylinder containing some water.

What range of volumes can be measured using the measuring cylinder?
markScheme: Answer: C – 0.0 to 10.0 cm³

parts.text:
A student used the measuring cylinder to measure the volume of a metal ring. The student tied the metal ring to some very thin string and lowered the ring into the measuring cylinder.

The student could have used thick string instead of thin string. How would using thick string have affected the measured volume of the metal ring?
options: The measured volume would be smaller.
The measured volume would not be affected.
The measured volume would be larger.
markScheme: Answer: C – The measured volume would be larger

parts.text: Table 1 shows the results. Calculate value X.
markScheme: 1 mark: X = **0.4** (cm³)

tables.caption: Volume measurements for the metal ring
headers: Volume of water and ring in cm³

parts.text:
The student measured the volume of the ring three times. The results were all the same.

Which of the following describes the student's results?
markScheme: Answer: B – The results are repeatable

parts.text:
The student used a balance to measure the mass of the ring. The student noticed that the balance had a reading of 0.02 g when there was no object on the balance.

How should the student correct this error after the mass of the ring had been measured?
markScheme: Answer: D – Subtract 0.02 from the measurement

parts.text: The diagrams X, Y and Z show how the particles are arranged in the three states of matter. Write the correct letter for each state.
segments: The diagram which shows the arrangement of particles in a liquid is

.

The diagram which shows the arrangement of particles in a gas is
markScheme: 1 mark: Liquid = **Z**
1 mark: Gas = **X**

parts.text: In a gas, the particles are...
markScheme: Answer: B – moving randomly

parts.text: In a solid, the forces between the particles are ___ the forces between the particles in a liquid.
markScheme: Answer: A – stronger than

parts.text:
During the day, a puddle of water dries up and disappears because the water particles move from the puddle into the air.

What process causes water particles to move from the puddle into the air?
markScheme: Answer: B – evaporation

parts.text: Describe one change in the weather which would cause the puddle of water to dry up faster.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any one of: becomes **windy** / temperature **increases** (accept sunny) / less **humid**

parts.text:
A large lump of ice was heated and changed state. The figure below shows how the temperature varied with time.

Which part of the figure shows when the ice was melting?
markScheme: Answer: B

parts.text: Which part of the figure shows when the water was boiling?
markScheme: Answer: D

parts.text: Which property of the water particles changes as the temperature of the water increases?
options: The kinetic energy of the particles
markScheme: Answer: A – The kinetic energy of the particles

parts.text:
Calculate the thermal energy needed to melt 0.250 kg of ice at 0 °C.

Specific latent heat of fusion of water = 334 000 J/kg

Use the equation: $E = m \times L$
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $E = 0.250 \times 334\,000$
1 mark: Final answer: **83 500 J**

parts.text: Complete the sentence. Choose the answer from the box.
segments: A substance is heated and changes directly from a solid to a gas. The substance
markScheme: 1 mark: **sublimates**

parts.text:
Figure 1 shows a Bunsen burner heating some water in a beaker. Eventually the water changes into steam.

Explain how the internal energy of the water changes as it is heated from 20 °C to 25 °C.
markScheme: 1 mark: The (mean) **kinetic energy** of the particles increases (accept the mean speed of the particles increases)
1 mark: Which increases the **internal energy** of the water

parts.text: How is the particle model used to explain the difference in density between a liquid and a gas?
options: Particles in a gas have less kinetic energy than particles in a liquid.
Particles in a gas have more potential energy than particles in a liquid.
Particles in a liquid are further apart than particles in a gas.
Particles in a liquid are larger than particles in a gas.
markScheme: Answer: B – Particles in a gas have more potential energy than particles in a liquid

parts.text:
A student measured the mass of boiling water that was turned into steam in five minutes.

Explain how the student could use this information to estimate the power output of the Bunsen burner in watts.
markScheme: 1 mark: Energy given to water $E = m L$ with **quantities defined**
1 mark: Use the specific latent heat of vaporisation to calculate the **energy transferred**
1 mark: Use the equation $P = \frac{E}{t}$ (or equivalent in words)
1 mark: Time should be converted to **seconds** (300 s)

parts.text: Write down the equation which links density (ρ), mass (m) and volume (V).
markScheme: Answer: A – $\rho = \frac{m}{V}$

parts.text:
A metal ring has a volume of 0.3 cm³. The density of this ring is 22 g/cm³.

Calculate the mass of this ring. Give your answer in grams.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $m = 22 \times 0.3$
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: $m = \rho \times V$
1 mark: Final answer: **6.6 g**

parts.text:
A student investigated the density of different fruits. Table 1 shows the results. The student determined the volume of each fruit using a displacement can and a measuring cylinder.

What other piece of equipment would the student need to determine the density of each fruit?
markScheme: 1 mark: **Balance** / scales

parts.text: Write down the equation which links density (ρ), mass (m) and volume (V).
markScheme: Answer: A – $\rho = \frac{m}{V}$

parts.text:
The mass of the apple was 85 g. The density of the apple was 0.68 g/cm³.

Calculate the volume of the apple. Give your answer in cm³.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $0.68 = \frac{85}{V}$
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: $V = \frac{m}{\rho} = \frac{85}{0.68}$
1 mark: Final answer: **125 cm³**

parts.text:
The student only measured the volume of each fruit once. The volume measurements cannot be used to show that the method to measure volume gives precise readings.

Give the reason why.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Repeat readings** of volume need to be taken to show that the readings are close together (accept 'the same')

parts.text:
A student investigated the density of different fruits. To determine the density of each fruit, the student measured the volume of each fruit. Figure 1 shows the equipment the student could have used.

Describe a method the student could have used to measure the volume of the lime.
markScheme: 1 mark: Use a **eureka/displacement can** (or a **measuring cylinder**)
1 mark: Fill the eureka/displacement can with water (up to the **spout**), or part fill a measuring cylinder with water
1 mark: Place **lime** in the eureka/displacement can (or measuring cylinder)
1 mark: Collect water that **overflows** (or record **new volume** of water)
1 mark: Use a measuring cylinder to measure volume of **displaced water** (or volume of lime = new volume - initial volume)
1 mark: Measure the **initial volume** of water before adding the lime

parts.text:
The student measured the volume of each fruit three times and then calculated a mean value.

The three measurements for a grape were 2.1 cm³, 2.1 cm³ and 2.4 cm³.

Calculate the mean value.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $(2.1 + 2.1 + 2.4) \div 3$
1 mark: Final answer: **2.2 cm³**

parts.text: What are the advantages of taking three measurements and calculating a mean value?
options: Allows anomalous results to be identified and ignored.
Improves the resolution of the volume measurement.
Increases the precision of the measured volumes.
Reduces the effect of random errors when using the equipment.
Stops all types of error when using the equipment.
markScheme: 1 mark: Allows anomalous results to be identified and ignored
1 mark: Reduces the effect of random errors when using the equipment

parts.text:
The mass of an apple was 84.0 g. The volume of the apple was 120 cm³.

Calculate the density of the apple. Give your answer in g/cm³.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $\rho = \frac{84.0}{120}$
1 mark: Final answer: **0.70 g/cm³**

parts.text:
A student wanted to determine the density of a small piece of rock.

Describe how the student could measure the volume of the piece of rock.
markScheme: 1 mark: Part fill a **measuring cylinder** with water (or use a **displacement/eureka can**)
1 mark: Measure the **initial volume** of water
1 mark: Place the **rock** in the water
1 mark: Measure the **final volume** (or collect displaced water)
1 mark: Volume of rock = **final volume − initial volume** (or measure volume of displaced water using a measuring cylinder)

parts.text:
The volume of the piece of rock was 18.0 cm³. The student measured the mass of the piece of rock as 48.6 g.

Calculate the density of the rock in g/cm³.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $\rho = \frac{48.6}{18.0}$
1 mark: Final answer: **2.70 g/cm³**

parts.text:
The graph below shows the densities of different types of rock.

What is the most likely type of rock that the student had?
markScheme: Answer: C – Limestone (density ≈ 2.71 g/cm³, closest to 2.70)

parts.text: Give one source of error that may have occurred when the student measured the volume of the rock.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Eye position** when reading the measuring cylinder (parallax error), or water level in displacement can not at level of spout, or not all displaced water collected

parts.text: How would the error you described in part (d) affect the measured volume of the rock?
markScheme: 1 mark: Volume would be **lower** or **higher** (depending on the error described)

questions.title: States of matter and latent heat
questions.subject: physics

parts.text:
Solid, liquid and gas are three different states of matter.

Describe the difference between the solid and gas states, in terms of the arrangement and movement of their particles.
markScheme: 1 mark: In a solid, particles **vibrate** about fixed positions
1 mark: In a solid, particles are **closely packed** (accept regular arrangement)
1 mark: In a gas, particles move **randomly** (accept freely / faster)
1 mark: In a gas, particles are **far apart**

parts.text: What is meant by 'specific latent heat of vaporisation'?
markScheme: 1 mark: Amount of energy required to change the state of a substance from **liquid** to **gas** (vapour)
1 mark: For **unit mass** / 1 kg (with no change in temperature)

parts.text:
While a kettle boils, 0.018 kg of water changes to steam.

Calculate the amount of energy required for this change.

Specific latent heat of vaporisation of water = $2.3 \times 10^6$ J/kg
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $E = 0.018 \times 2.3 \times 10^6$
1 mark: Final answer: **41 400 J** (accept 41 000 or $4.1 \times 10^4$)

parts.text:
Figure 1 shows how temperature varies with time for a substance as it is heated. The graph is not drawn to scale.

Explain what is happening to the substance in sections AB and BC of the graph.
markScheme: 1 mark: Section AB — the substance is **changing state** from solid to liquid / **melting**
1 mark: Section AB — the temperature remains **steady** / constant (during the change of state)
1 mark: Section BC — the **temperature** of the liquid **rises** / increases
1 mark: Section BC — until it reaches the **boiling point**

parts.text:
A student used a measuring cylinder containing some water to measure the volume of a metal ring. When measuring the volume, the student's eye was in line with the level of the water.

Which type of error would have been caused if the student's eye was not in line with the level of the water?
markScheme: Answer: A – Random error

parts.text:
The student tied a piece of thick string to the metal ring and lowered the ring into the water.

Suggest one reason why the student should have used thin string instead of thick string.
markScheme: 1 mark: Thin string would affect the volume measurement **less** (thin string would displace less water than thick string)

parts.text:
The true volume of the ring was 0.44 cm³. Even without using the string, the measuring cylinder could not give an accurate value for the volume of the ring.

Give one reason why.
markScheme: 1 mark: The **resolution** of the measuring cylinder is 0.2 cm³ (cannot measure to 2 decimal places)

parts.text:
The student used a balance to measure the mass of the ring. After the ring was removed from the balance, the reading on the balance was 0.02 g.

How could the student use the readings from the balance to determine the correct mass of the ring?
markScheme: 1 mark: **Subtract 0.02 g** from the measured value

parts.text:
The student determined that the density of the ring was 21 500 kg/m³. The volume of the ring was 0.44 cm³.

Calculate the mass of the ring. Give your answer in kg.

Note: 1 cm³ = 1 × 10⁻⁶ m³
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $m = 21\,500 \times 4.4 \times 10^{-7}$ (converting 0.44 cm³ = $4.4 \times 10^{-7}$ m³)
1 mark: Correct rearrangement: $m = \rho \times V$
1 mark: Final answer: **0.00946 kg** (accept $9.46 \times 10^{-3}$ kg)

parts.text:
A company is developing a system which can heat up and melt ice on roads in the winter. During the summer, the black surface of the road will heat up in the sunshine. This energy will be stored in a large amount of soil deep under the road surface.

The system could work well because the road surface is black. Suggest why.
markScheme: 1 mark: Black is a good **absorber** of (infrared) **radiation**

parts.text: What is meant by specific latent heat of fusion?
markScheme: 1 mark: Amount of energy required to change the state of a substance from **solid** to **liquid**
1 mark: For **unit mass** / 1 kg (with no change in temperature)

parts.text:
Calculate the amount of energy required to melt 15 kg of ice at 0 °C.

Specific latent heat of fusion of ice = $3.4 \times 10^5$ J/kg
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct substitution: $E = 15 \times 3.4 \times 10^5$
1 mark: Final answer: **$5.1 \times 10^6$ J** (accept 5 100 000)

parts.text:
A student investigated how the melting point of ice varies with the mass of salt added. The student added salt to crushed ice and measured the temperature at which the ice melted.

State one variable that the student should have controlled.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Mass of ice** (accept volume/weight/amount/quantity of ice)

parts.text: During the investigation the student stirred the crushed ice. Suggest two reasons why.
options: To raise the melting point of the ice
To lower the melting point of the ice
To distribute the salt throughout the ice
To keep all the ice at the same temperature
To reduce energy transfer from the surroundings to the ice
markScheme: 1 mark: To distribute the salt throughout the ice
1 mark: To keep all the ice at the same temperature

parts.text: Table 1 shows the data that the student obtained. Describe the pattern shown in Table 1.
markScheme: 1 mark: **Melting point decreases** as the mass of salt is increased (accept negative correlation)

tables.caption: Effect of salt on the melting point of ice
headers: Mass of salt added in grams

parts.text:
Undersoil electrical heating systems are used in greenhouses. A cable just below the ground carries an electric current. One greenhouse system has a power output of 0.50 kW.

Calculate the energy transferred in 2 minutes.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct unit conversions: 0.50 kW = **500 W** and 2 minutes = **120 s**
1 mark: Correct substitution: $E = 500 \times 120$
1 mark: Final answer: **60 000 J** (accept 60 kJ)

parts.text:
A local council wants to keep a particular section of a road clear of ice in the winter.

Describe the advantages and disadvantages of keeping the road clear of ice using:
- energy storage
- salt
- undersoil electrical heating.
markScheme: 1 mark: Energy storage advantage — no **fuel costs**
1 mark: Energy storage advantage — no **environmental effects** (during operation)
1 mark: Energy storage disadvantage — **expensive** to set up and maintain
1 mark: Energy storage disadvantage — dependent on **(summer) weather**
1 mark: Salt advantage — easily **available** / **cheap**
1 mark: Salt disadvantage — can **damage** trees / plants / drinking water / cars
1 mark: Undersoil heating advantage — not dependent on **weather** / can be switched **on and off**
1 mark: Undersoil heating disadvantage — **costly** / bad for the **environment**
